expanded_description: Systems of equations and systems of inequalities are powerful tools for modeling real-world situations. While equations give exact solutions, inequalities describe regions of possible solutions. This review brings together all the concepts from solving systems of equations (graphing, substitution, elimination) and systems of inequalities (graphing, interpreting feasible regions, linear programming), helping you see the connections and choose the right approach for any problem.

core_concept.principle:
Systems of equations and inequalities share the concept of multiple conditions that must be satisfied simultaneously. Key differences:
• **Equations**: Solutions are points (or sets of points) that make all equations true. Methods include graphing, substitution, and elimination.
• **Inequalities**: Solutions are regions in the plane. Solved by graphing, with optimal solutions found via linear programming at corner points.
core_concept.explanation: Think of equations as precise targets—you must hit exactly the right spot. Inequalities are like zones—you can be anywhere within an area. Both involve multiple constraints, but the nature of the answer is different. This review helps you see the big picture and choose the right tool for each job.

sections.introduction: Let's start with a quick comparison of the key differences between systems of equations and systems of inequalities.

introduction_image.alt: Comparison table of equations and inequalities
introduction_image.caption: Figure 8.8.2: Equations vs inequalities comparison.

key_concept.definition:
| Feature | Systems of Equations | Systems of Inequalities |
|---------|---------------------|------------------------|
| Solution | Point(s) of intersection | Region of the plane |
| Number of solutions | 0, 1, or infinitely many | Usually infinite |
| Graphing | Lines intersect | Overlapping shaded regions |
| Methods | Graphing, substitution, elimination | Graphing, test points |
| Optimization | Not applicable | Linear programming |
| Special cases | Parallel (no solution), coincident (infinite) | No overlap (no solution), unbounded regions |
key_concept.context: This table summarizes the key similarities and differences. Keep it in mind as you work through review problems.

worked_examples.title: Identifying System Type

image.alt: Problems to identify as equations or inequalities
image.caption: Figure 8.8.4: Identify each as a system of equations or inequalities.

worked_examples.problem:
Identify each as a system of equations or a system of inequalities:
a) $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 12 \\ x - y = 4 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} y > 2x - 1 \\ y \leq -x + 3 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} x + y \geq 5 \\ 2x - y < 3 \end{cases}$
d) $\begin{cases} 3x - 2y = 6 \\ 4x + y = 8 \end{cases}$
worked_examples.final_answer: a) Equations, b) Inequalities, c) Inequalities, d) Equations
worked_examples.concept_applied: The presence of = vs inequality symbols determines the system type.

sections.introduction: Let's review the three methods for solving systems of equations: graphing, substitution, and elimination.

introduction_image.caption: Figure 8.8.6: Solving systems of equations review.

key_concept.definition:
• **Graphing**: Graph both lines; intersection point is solution. Best for visualization, checking, and when solution is integer.
• **Substitution**: Solve one equation for a variable, substitute into the other. Best when a variable is already isolated or has coefficient 1.
• **Elimination**: Add or subtract equations to eliminate a variable. Best when coefficients are opposites or can be easily made opposites.
key_concept.context: Choose the method based on the system's structure.

worked_examples.title: Solving Systems of Equations Review
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each system using an appropriate method:
a) $\begin{cases} y = 2x - 3 \\ 3x + 2y = 11 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 12 \\ 4x - 3y = 6 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} 3x - 2y = 7 \\ 5x + 3y = 20 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.step: c) Elimination (multiply first by 3, second by 2)

worked_examples.concept_applied: Choose the most efficient method based on the system's structure.

sections.introduction: Systems of equations can have no solution or infinitely many solutions. Recognizing these cases is important.

key_concept.definition:
• **No solution (inconsistent)**: Lines are parallel (same slope, different intercepts). When solving algebraically, you'll get a contradiction like $0 = 5$.
• **Infinitely many solutions (dependent)**: Lines are coincident (same slope and intercept). When solving, you'll get an identity like $0 = 0$.
key_concept.context: Recognizing these cases prevents incorrect conclusions about solutions.

image.alt: Examples of parallel and coincident lines
image.caption: Figure 8.8.11: Special case examples.

worked_examples.title: Identifying Special Cases
worked_examples.problem:
Determine whether each system has one solution, no solution, or infinitely many solutions:
a) $\begin{cases} 2x + 3y = 6 \\ 4x + 6y = 12 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} y = 2x - 1 \\ y = 2x + 3 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} 3x - 2y = 5 \\ 6x - 4y = 10 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.calculation: All ratios equal → dependent → infinitely many solutions
All ratios equal → dependent → infinitely many solutions

worked_examples.final_answer: a) Infinitely many, b) No solution, c) Infinitely many
worked_examples.concept_applied: Use slope comparison or ratio method to identify special cases.

sections.introduction: Graphing systems of inequalities requires careful attention to line types and shading to identify the feasible region.

key_concept.definition:
To graph a system of inequalities:
1. Graph each boundary line (solid for ≤ or ≥, dashed for < or >).
2. Shade the appropriate side for each inequality (use test points or above/below rules).
3. The feasible region is where all shadings overlap.
4. Corner points are intersections of boundary lines within the feasible region.
key_concept.context: Accuracy in graphing is essential for correctly identifying the feasible region.

worked_examples.problem:

b) $\begin{cases} x \geq 0, y \geq 0 \\ 2x + y \leq 8 \\ x + 2y \leq 8 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.explanation: Overlap is a triangular region between the lines.

image.caption: Figure 8.8.23: Feasible region for system b.

sections.introduction: Linear programming finds optimal solutions within a feasible region by evaluating the objective at corner points.

key_concept.definition:
Linear programming steps:
1. Identify decision variables and write constraints.
2. Graph the feasible region and find corner points.
3. Write the objective function to maximize or minimize.
4. Evaluate the objective at each corner point.
5. Choose the best value (largest for max, smallest for min).
key_concept.context: Linear programming is used in business, manufacturing, and resource allocation to make optimal decisions.

sections.introduction: Knowing which method to use for a given problem is a key skill. This section helps you make that choice.

key_concept.definition:
For systems of equations:
• **Graphing**: When you need a visual check or approximate answer.
• **Substitution**: When a variable is already isolated or has coefficient 1.
• **Elimination**: When coefficients are opposites or can be easily made opposites.

For systems of inequalities:
• **Graphing** is the primary method.
• **Linear programming** adds optimization.
key_concept.context: Choosing the right method saves time and reduces errors.

worked_examples.problem:
Suggest the most efficient method for each:
a) $\begin{cases} y = 3x - 2 \\ 2x + 5y = 11 \end{cases}$
b) $\begin{cases} 3x + 2y = 12 \\ 3x - 2y = 6 \end{cases}$
c) $\begin{cases} y > 2x - 1 \\ y \leq -x + 3 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.step: a) First equation solved for y

step_by_step.explanation: Need to graph to find region

sections.introduction: Apply all your skills to a variety of problems involving systems of equations and inequalities.

worked_examples.title: Mixed Review Set
worked_examples.problem:
Solve each problem:
1) Solve the system: $\begin{cases} 3x - 2y = 7 \\ 4x + y = 13 \end{cases}$
2) Graph the system: $\begin{cases} y \geq 2x - 1 \\ y < -x + 3 \end{cases}$
3) Classify the system: $\begin{cases} 2x + 4y = 8 \\ x + 2y = 4 \end{cases}$
4) Maximize $P = 40x + 30y$ subject to $x \geq 0$, $y \geq 0$, $2x + y \leq 100$, $x + 2y \leq 80$.
5) Determine if $(3,2)$ is a solution to $\begin{cases} y > 2x - 4 \\ y \leq -x + 5 \end{cases}$

step_by_step.explanation: Second equation multiplied by 2 gives $2x + 4y = 8$, same as first

step_by_step.calculation: Fails first inequality, so not a solution

worked_examples.final_answer:
1) $(3,1)$
2) Graph as shown
3) Consistent dependent
4) Max $P=2200$ at $(40,20)$
5) No, not a solution

summary: This review has covered both systems of equations and systems of inequalities, highlighting their similarities and differences. Systems of equations are solved by finding intersection points using graphing, substitution, or elimination. They can have one solution, no solution (parallel lines), or infinitely many solutions (coincident lines). Systems of inequalities are solved by graphing to find feasible regions, with solutions being entire areas of the plane. Linear programming extends inequality systems to find optimal solutions by evaluating an objective function at corner points. When choosing a method, consider the structure of the system: substitution for isolated variables, elimination for opposite coefficients, graphing for visualization or inequalities. Special cases must be recognized to avoid incorrect conclusions. Mastering both types of systems provides a comprehensive toolkit for modeling and solving real-world problems involving multiple conditions and constraints.
